all_paragraphs: The pandas development team just officially release pandas version 1.0.0 on Jan. 29, 2020. In this article, I’ll answer your burning questions, discuss the major changes, and show you how to start using the new version today. 😀
Note, this article has been update to reflect the official release. 🎉

Pandas is the most popular Python library for cleaning, exploring, and manipulating data. It adds named rows and columns to NumPy’s ndarray data structure. And it adds many convenience methods that make working with data easier. Pandas is a big part of the reason Python has become the dominant language for data scientists and data engineers.

Not really. The 1.0 label doesn’t signify a massive departure from 0.25.3, the stable version as of January 22, 2020 (when this article was originally written). As you’ll see, there aren’t that many big changes.

The 1.0 release also doesn’t signify that the language has reached a major maturation point. Pandas is a fairly stable library that has been used in production code for years. Wes McKinney starting working on the library in 2008. GitHub shows it has been used in about 170,000 GitHub repositories as of this writing. 👍
The changes in 1.0 might introduce a bit more complexity in the short term, but they put the language on a better foundation for the long term.
In addition to the usual bug fixes and minor API cleanup, pandas 1.0.0 introduces a few major features.

In pandas 0.25, a DataFrame could have three different values— np.nan, None or pd.NaT —to represent missing data, depending on the dtype of the column. If you want the details, see my article about the confusing mess that is missing data values in pandas here.
The biggest hiccup with missing values that many folks face is that an integer column with a missing value automatically gets cast into float. Yikes. 🙀

This current state of affairs is largely due to the capabilities of the underlying NumPy library. In an effort to improve the situation, the pandas development team created a new value to represent missing data for several dtypes. As explained in the 1.0 docs:

Starting from pandas 1.0, an experimental pd.NA value (singleton) is available to represent scalar missing values. At this moment, it is used in the nullable integer, boolean and dedicated string data types as the missing value indicator.
The goal of pd.NA is [to] provide a “missing” indicator that can be used consistently across data types (instead of np.nan, None or pd.NaT depending on the data type).

In the longer term, a single value for missing data and avoiding auto-casting an integer column with missing data into a float sounds great! 👏 In the short term, it creates a few more things to learn and remember.

One gotcha with the new pd.NA is that you can’t compare it directly to a value in a boolean condition. So no == with pd.NA. Instead, you can use df.isna() to return a boolean mask for missing values in your DataFrame.
Let’s look at the three dtypes that can hold pd.NA.

If you want to use the new pd.NA and avoid typecasting your int to a float, right now you must specify the special nullable integer dtype Int64 — note the capital I. This dtype is not the same as the standard int64 NumPy dtype you know and love. ❤️
Here’s the old way to make a DataFrame with an integer dtype column (with pandas and NumPy imported under their usual aliases):
Note the automatic type casting to a float.
Here’s the way to create a column that can handle pd.NA.
Just specify dtype=”Int64" when creating a Series or DataFrame and you get the nullable integer dtype. Notice the difference:
The column still has ints! And there’s the new <NA>. 👍
The trickiness around int64 and Int64 — with just a a capital I for the pandas version and a lowercase i for the existing NumPy version seems like it might cause some confusion. ☹️
A bool dtype column gets cast into an object dtype if missing values are introduced. If you want a boolean integer column with missing pd.NA values, then designate the column with a dtype of boolean.
Again, this is cool, but the boolean dtype seems likely to get confused with the existing bool dtype.
Let’s look a the new string dtype.

A new, more intuitive, data type for text data sounds like a great idea to me, at least at first glance. The object dtype is the default catchall for text data and any miscellaneous data that doesn’t fit into another category.
The string dtype uses pd.NA for missing values, provides memory savings, and communicates you only want text values in a column. For now, you need to specify you want it. Here’s how you do that:
The short-term downside of these changes is that there are now even more nuances to missing values and dtypes. ☹️
To make the transition a little easier, there is now a pandas DataFrame method convert_dtypes().

Call convert_dtypes() on a DataFrame or Series and pandas will attempt to convert each column to a dtype that support pd.NA. (those are the new dtypes discussed above). Read more about it in the fancy new docs!
Hat tip to Kevin Markham for pointing me to this method.

So although there might be more nuances to learn, the upside of the new data types is that pandas has taken a big step toward a more intuitive treatment of missing values throughout the API. It seems like a necessary growing pain to me. 😀

Pandas 1.0 is here. It’s a good time to start using it! 👍

If you’ve been keeping up with recent pandas releases and doing something about those warnings that pop up, updating to 1.0 shouldn’t be too rough. However, many of those warnings you saw in previous versions of pandas will now error, so be careful. 😀
